instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PM_BATLOW: What is PM_BATLOW? PM_BATLOW is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on.
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.3V3_S4: What is 3V3_S4? This is an abbreviation of PP3V3_S4, a 3.3v power rail when the machine is in an S4 state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message: No fan spin on this. Does 8.28V basically =8.1V on this board? what's the threshhold for PPBUS to satisfy?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message:
Exact measured voltage depends by multimeter used too.
A reading in range of 8.35-8.6V, is good enough.

Sometime boards boot with incorrect <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, so you should check more signals there.
Pay atention to battery bus first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message: Does the PPBUS-G3H stay low because the SMC detects or thinks it detects over current?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message:
SMC cannot negotiate with <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> the output voltage.
This happen because I2C battery bus is blocked, or SMC is bad; less probably bad <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
Check voltage and diode mode to ground on SCL/SDA lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message:
smbus SMC 5 g3 SCL is 2.93V
SDA is 2.99V

SCL .523V drop and SDA is .519V Drop. 

Going to swap the SMC

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message: Well SMC swap went well. somehow fucked my SCL SDA as they were both shorted but at the ISL! replaced that shorts on sCL and SDA gone and 2nd ISL wasn't putting out proper voltages. 3rd try on ISL and PPBUS now at 8.65V but no fan spin. *face palm*

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message:
Step by step, you've got correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at least.

Now check Power On Sequence signals and voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is .8V diode drop red to ground is .379V
<SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?
What about <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> =0V
/SUS = 0V
SMC Adapter EN= 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW</SIGNAL> _L=   PULSES 0.5-3V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>,= 3.4
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>,= 3.24V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.4V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message:
Did you take SMC from donor board, same model?

PLEASE post accurate information!!!

<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> requires <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> requires <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.
So, correct your measurments...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message:
Obviously not getting consistent voltage on the board. WHen i went to recheck PPBUS was pulsing again and ended up replacing R/<CAPACITOR>C7105</CAPACITOR>
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> =3.34V
/SUS = 3.3V
SMC Adapter EN= 3.44V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW</SIGNAL> _L= 3.34V and now steady
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>,= 3.4
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>,= 3.23V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.44V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is 0V diode drop red to ground is .374V
<SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is 0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message: NO change at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBT_L</SIGNAL> when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message: Check the 4 (four) PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message:
these?
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>
All over 3V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> really drops from 3V to 0V?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message: yes. when I jumper the two points at top of board, i see the drop also at <RESISTOR>R5170</RESISTOR>. Oddly I have another board with <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> issue I just posted.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message:
Then you have PCH, or SMC problem.
You can change the SMC (from donor board), for test.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message:
Replaced SMC and now I do get at drop at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBT_L</SIGNAL> to .35V when jumpering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>
Still 0V at <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is 0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message:
Now check for pulse at all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals at same time of drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
Be sure <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> is steady high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message: NO pulse a <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5</SIGNAL>/4 when dropping <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message:
"Be sure <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> is steady high."
???

Looks like bad PCH...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message: yes I checked steady high. any sense in putting any flux/heat to PCH?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message: You can try, as looks like last option anyway...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message: Try 100-200 first? Then try reflow if nada? Why temp will chip possibly burn?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message:
Do not exceed 200 degrees.
You need to burn eventually accumulated crap; no need to melt the balls.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.28V
threads.message: 200 Celsius I assume
